Thats the way you do it. If I have a company thats trading for 100 and Im like okay if it hits 125 Im out. Ill just look at the call chain and figure out how many months out I need to go to get something worth my time and sell a 125. If Im looking to get off something just to sell it rather than use a limit order I will sell a weekly atm call. I get a little premium and if they take the shares, thats fine, if it expires Ill just sell another one. Using options in this fashion is a great way to collect extra money. So, whatever you want to sell those shares for, look how far out you have to go to get some reasonable money for it and write them. Theres nothing wrong with selling three, six, 12 months out if you bake in and expected return because if you get it, cool let them have it, if you dont you keep the premium

Well, volatility changes on most companies so the most ideal time to sell them is after a large movement in share price. The thing about selling weeklies though is youre going to get hit quite a bit so like I said if you want to get off some shares. Weeklies are perfect. If you have a 100 company, just look at the values of 100, 101, 102 etc. see what kind of money is in each call and what makes the most sense. Like you said you wanted to get that position size down a little bit, just short however many contracts are necessary to get down to the size you want to be at, with any luck youll get to do it at least once or twice before your shares get called Premiums should be pretty good tomorrow since we have the Fed on Wednesday

replies.text: uBossie81 I have a few questions 1. How is it that IBRXs accumulated deficit of 3.2 billion is more than half of SoonShiongs net worth, if he didnt deliberately saddle it with debt Im not saying he did Im just asking? 2. If IBRX only has enough cash and cash equivalents to fund operations through at least 12 months, doesnt that mean a share dilution is very likely in the near future? Wouldnt IBRX be cutting things a bit close if they dont do it within the next 3 months? 3. The stock price is lower today than it was when the FDA approval was given. What does this mean for sales? Does it for example mean that other drugs are being preferred, over Anktiva? Does it mean that Anktivas efficacy has been exaggerated, since its not effective on its own but has to be taken alongside BCG? 4. Which other drugs are competing with Anktiva in the treatment of NMIBC, and how do their sales compare with those of Anktiva? 5. Are there any official dates or timelines by which UK approval is expected? 6. You say his plane has been at Heathrow Airport for this month. Is it likely that he is pushing for UK approval, so he can then announce some shares dilution?
Great DD, thanks

I believe the launch going well

Hi. 1. Delays in approval play a part. Complete response letter FDA. Further, the enormous sales team comes with a huge price tag. Trials are extremely expensive, I believe 505k 150k per participant., depending on the type of drugtreatment. 2. Yes. Share dilution is possible. However, it is my opinion the will partner to create liquidity. Soon owns 80 of the stock, so he has in interest too. 3. Look at Akebia, Iovance, Coherus, Xfor and others that had PDUFAapproval. Approval means nothing, IBRX was in the luxury position of being able to ship 2 weeks after approval. Unique. However, the market still needs to be informed, trained, insurance deals covered. An approval, as with the given examples, are in indication of future value. Especially when it does not concern Big Pharma. 4. Keytruda and Opdivo I believe. If you look at Opdivo wiki, you can see a approval path I think Anktiva has the same timeline. 5. UK is my guess. Not fact. It is simply logic. The fastest to obtain. 6. UK approval, in my opinion, will go with a partnership. I do not see how they can not. If they do not partner, they will need to dilute. With Bio stock anything is possible. You have to be willing to see red. A partner can bee in many forms, but if this occurs there will be a big investment my guess 500,000,000 minimum and hefty milestone payments for each indication.

Welcome Sir. It is evident the current situation is not ideal. If an ATM was applied, it would have been done already. If dilution would take place, I am guessing a direct placement. Oberman also has a massive interest 200 million and I am sure there are some negatives to be found in sec filing. This nugget is glanced over easily. Also, he clearly is a philanthropist, his age 73 or so, I think this is his legacy no way no how he is going to let that go bankrupt or be spoiled by monetary issues.

So, keytruda is currently mercks cash cow. Its patent is also running out. Anktiva has been shown to improve efficacy lower side effects as an adjuvant to keytruda. If they had anktiva, they could extend keytrudas patents on that basis. Their own trials in this direction have all recently failed. They are an obvious candidate, but immunitybio has secured a deal with the serum institute of India and is filing for phase 3 for non small cell lung cancer as per news today. So either theyre pressuring or they are going it alone. Hope that is interesting context to you.
Looks like you are not familiar with bio business.Read about the big pharma business operations, acquisitions and drug trials process etc. before starting to investin biotech.

Yes, I read about the India move some months ago. It seems like its a very wise move on the part of Soon, since Anktiva is so dependent on a regular supply of BCG. He sounds like an incredible visionary lets hope that it translates into full approval and usage of Anktiva, and a nice appreciation in the stock price.

This is indeed very interesting, thanks for sharing it. This information suggests to me that ImmunityBio is trying to resist being bought out by Big Pharma, and instead wants to use deals to make profit on its own, growing its own share price independently.

ubamadesi Im not sure where youre trying to go with your comment, but Ill just say the following 1. If by bio business you mean biotechs as a whole, well nobody is ever going to be familiar with all of them, and each biotech has its own idiosyncracies and unique selling points. Therefore, we ALL need to read about bio business. Also, as far as getting familiar is concerned, asking questions here is actually part of getting familiar with the sector and learning more about it. Nobody has a monopoly on knowledge. 2 Big Pharma and biotechs are not the same thing. A financial win for a Biotech company may barely move the financial needle for a Big Pharma company thats worth multiples of billions, depending on the amount of sales of the drug. If a biotechs drug is not the only drug on the market for a given illness, the money made from that drugs market share will be limited, since the Total Addressable Market will be shared with the competing drugs. There are also drugs that most of the public who need them will never see, due to the unfortunate fact that those drugs are too expensive to be massproduced for the wider market. 3 A companys revenue is very different from its stock price action. Even when a drug is sold to the public, it isnt guaranteed to translate to significant stock price increase. If a biotechs stock price doesnt move much, then that biotech isnt attractive to private investors, even if it remains desirable for a big pharma company to invest in it.

replies.text: My main account is with Schwab but I opened a HSA with fidelity. The fact that fidelity sweeps your cash balance into a money market is reason enough to pick fidelity. I havent switched because of the headache and I just actively manage my cash in a money market act with Schwab but if I was starting from scratch Id pick fidelity.

Fidelity allows for partial shares of ETFs and Stocks. Schwab only allows partial of some stocks on the SP. The source of the funds can come from your brokerage or directly from your bank account. Fidelity allows automatic investing of any stockETF. Schwab only has it for mutual funds. Edit I switched all but my individual stocks from Schwab to Fidelity for the above reasons.
I am with Schwab after being ripped off by Ameriprise and Facet. Have had no issues with Schwab. Good customer service and easy to use for my needs. Cant complain

Coming from TD Ameritrade I am still disappointed with Schwab. Compared to their pc app Schwab is not nearly as easy to use but it does provide the info if you have time to drill and search. I use both TOS for trading and pc app for account and portfolio management. I am planning on moving my managed accounts out of Schwab since they like to use their ETFs over better performing Vangard, etc. I will leave my trading accounts with Schwab just because of TOS.
Schwab for me simple af and I love that. The dark mode is the best. Easy on the eye
Fidelity has 0 fee funds

I have both. Its no big deal wit move stuff to sgov or usfr with free trades. I prefer tos. But I dont trade much anymore. Fidelity does dumb crap where you need like 1 million to trade zero day options. Tda basically banned trading on options of gme and AMC. You couldnt sell covered calls or cash backed puts with the ap. You had to call in and phone trade. Fidelity and Vanguard I think are the only 2 that didnt cut off options trading. Vanguard is no leveraged or crypto. Fidelity also no futures. I keep a couple of accounts due to potential fraud or and or systems crashing. Once I retire I dont want to risk having one get cut off for whatever reason. Its a minor inconvenience with taxed as its another form but I just report totals and upload the document.

Im with fidelity and have never used Schwab no reason other than thats just how things happened. Ive honestly never had a problem with fidelitys UIUX both the app and the website. iOS app has always been good. In my opinion, that shouldnt be the main reason to choose a broker. Obviously, if the appwebsite are shit then sure, dont go with that broker, but the main thing you should consider is which company is better for your money. Judging by your list, fidelity wins on that metric. Also, Ive had all good experiences with their customer service. My employer payed out our pensions last year and it was seamless to call fidelity to roll it over into an IRA.

Im happy with fidelity. I havent used Schwab, but have used a few others, and currently have a ibkr account. Ive been contemplating just sticking with fidelity exclusively. Between the app, trader pro, and their website, I feel like they have you covered with screnners and and all the chart indicators you really need. I havent noticed slippage yet when using limit orders, or anything like that. Doing anything over the phone seems easy and pleasant.

I agree with you about Schwabs app being glitchy. I have given up trying to do any trades on the app and only use it to do research. I only trade on PC because Schwabs app will just freeze up every time I try to do a trade on my phone. Also Schwab has locked people out of their accounts twice this year already which never happened to me before on any other brokerage. The only reason I am using Schwab is because I really liked TD Ameritrade and they were purchased by Schwab this year so I didnt really have a choice. I wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt and you can still use the ThinkorSwim platform with Schwab so that is something that I dont want to give up. I am crossing my fingers hoping they will get better because I would really rather avoid switching brokerages and having to learn a new skill set for trading. If I were to move I might choose Chase, but I have heard that Fidelity is also a good choice. Good luck with whatever you decide! Edit I wanted to add that another thing I do like about Schwab is that you can trade in afterhours premarket, set up as many automatic orders as you want with no fees for equity tradesnot options, and I can spend twice as much money as I actually have if I want to not sure if that is a good thing or not...lol.

I have accounts at both. I was switched to Schwab when they bought TD Ameritrade. After the switch, I was extremely disappointed with Schwab performance. Here are the things I did not like versus Fidelity 1 Fidelity auto sweeps my cash to a money market account paying 5. Schwab does not and pays a paltry 0.35 on this cash. 2 Fidelity pays out dividends to customers the same day companies pay out. Schwab holds this cash for an extra day and pays out a day later. 3 Schwabs site experienced 3 crashes at the open when I was looking to trade. Never had a problem with Fidelity in the 10 years I have had an account with them. 4 My account contacts at Fidelity are great and take care of things within days of requesting. My account rep at TD Ameritrade was awesome and moved over to Schwab. He is super frustrated by them due to their poor performance and inability to compete with other brokerage firms as they are not competitive. 5 Schwab only allows a single phone number for two factor authentication. Fidelity allows two phone numbers to be set up to access an account via two factor authentication. I want both my wife and myself to be able to access accounts in case something happens to the other spouse. I ended up moving a multimillion account from Schwab to Fidelity due to Schwabs poor performance. Fidelity paid me an incentive bonus of several thousand dollars to move the money to them. I am much happier.
Having both is the move, has been the move and will always be the move!
Schwab is known to crash during periods of high use since they took all of TD Ameritrade and brought everyone over. If it were easier? Id have left them.
The Schwab UI is ass. I was forced into this shit from TD and I hate it. Because of that I say fidelity. Anything is better what Schwab mobile app

When I started investing in CDs and treasuries at Schwab, the 0.1 yield on the sweep became a problem, so I moved all of my accounts to Vanguard. Vanguard pays better on their sweep than Fidelity, usually 5.15 vs, 4.95.

FWIW, I was in the same exact boat and decided to move everything into Fidelity. Ive already used their customer service twice and they were solid on both occasions. I also did not like the Schwab app.
Dont

I have accounts at both, with my bigger account at Schwab. The biggest reason is that I hate using Fidelitys app and website. I absolutely loathe them, especially the app. Options permissions are different between the two of them, so somehow I can trade spreads at Fidelity at their level 2, but I cannot trade spreads at Schwab because I only have level 2 there and thats a level 3 permission. So Im doing some options trading there. They also have student accounts, so I have accounts for my kids there that Im able to access and manage. My larger account thats primarily just buy and hold is at Schwab. I wish Fidelity would do something about their absolutely atrocious app, because then Id likely keep everything in one place there.

Since you asked for advice dont, keep accounts separate. No institution is bulletproof. Things happen. Things that eventually get resolved, but you would sleep much better if you only had portion of your assets having an issue, rather than all of you assets. From someone who has retail account with IBKR, retirementRSU vesting accounts with Fidelity and HSA through Schwab. All platforms are great. All three are great institutions. Actually, someone else, who doesnt have a monopolistic market position could step in and pay Apple to be the default search engine for iOS. IANAL but in short Simply being a monopoly or near monopoly does not trigger antitrust issues. The government is loath to punish a company simply for being successful. For a nonmonopoly provider, making exclusive contracts for placement or positioning of your product is also not something that would trigger antitrust issues. However, when you have a dominant market position, as Google has with Search, and you create exclusive contracts for placement of your product that exclude other providers, it can trigger antitrust issues under the Sherman Act. There are several remedies but the most obvious is the deal between Google and Apple to make Google the default search engine on iOS will be unwound. Instead, Apple will likely have to give iOS users a choice of search engines. Google will likely appeal so the final determination could be months or years away. The immediate impact once appeals, etc. are concluded is likely pretty small most iOS users will likely choose Google as their search engine because it is by far the most popular search engine across all platforms and has the best recognition in the market. Google still dominates on Windows where Bing is installed as the default search engine. One of the first things people do with a new Windows install is disable Bing, Edge, Cortana and OneDrive. Long term however, this will open an opportunity for other search engines and search technologies.

The fundamental problem most rstocks users dont understand is that very capable LLMs require a huge amount of computing resources. Its estimated that it takes around 50 Nvidia H100 GPUs clustered together just to fit GPT4 into memory. GPT4 is reportedly 1.7 trillion parameters. Apple Intelligences local model is around 2 billion parameters because thats all a mobile device can do in 2024. In other words, GPT4 is 850x larger than Apple Intelligences local model. Its obvious to anyone who understands AI that Apple Intelligence is a many years long roadmap that will have exponential improvements each year. Were in the baby years of AI. This notion that AI doesnt meet marketing hype is silly. Its not a feature you build once and it never gets updated again. Its likely a very long march towards a true AI digital assistance like Jarvis in Iron Man. In the past, people upgraded their iPhones for various reasons from faster CPUsGPUs, faster modems, better cameras, bigger screens, better battery life. All of those have reached maturity and are reaching diminishing returns. Apple now has a new lever to pull. Buy iPhone 17, its 4x more intelligent than iPhone 16. Buy iPhone 18, it can now run a 20 billion parameter LLM. From here on out, Apple Intelligence should get better exponentially.
But the use cases will likely remain the same

While I dont think Zuck is outright lying, because AI long driven more effective digital ads, the eyeopener for me this quarter was seeing Google, then Microsoft, then Meta reported very substantial increases in capital expenditures. As a disclaimer, I own NVDA and TSM substantial positions and recently added more on the pullback, and will ride out any swings between now and late August when NVDA reports, which better be a really great report or it will tank, but it probably will be great or everyone will be scrambling to find out where the spend went. Right now, investors are obviously getting skeptical about AI cap ex, which will eventually result in lower mag 7 cap ex, which will be really bad for semis, but thats a second derivative effect and the arms race definitely isnt ending right now. Ill seriously shave my toptier semi positions when these cap ex numbers start dropping in a meaningful way or when LLM traininginference ASICs start eating NVDAs lunch. As far as I know, AVGO just added to a meaningful buyandhold position and TSM are the way for a nonaccredited investor to play the eventual ASICs wave, but NVDA could also come out with their own ASICs. But right now, the megacap CEOs are really excited about AI and they have the money to spend on it. They still have good cash flow and can still spend big if they want to. I think LLMs and other applications of transformers will continue to get better, theyll be faster, smaller models will be better, and context windows will be larger before the LLMs start spitting out hallucinations and functionally break. With the right training techniques, which are still evolving, the transformer that LLMs is based on can remarkably improve on really overdetermined data, which breaks what I used to know about signals analysis and training oldschool neural networks. I think we are going through a routine lowvolume summer pullback with hedge funds piling into the previously lagging R2K, which makes momentum plays swing like crazy. But, hedge funds will be back, and theyll long the same positions they shorted months earlier, and then theyll short them again. Its fine for investors to hold the feet of megacaps to the fire, but that just brings their PE multiples closer to normal for a tech stock. Other position disclaimers Google small LT buyandhold position, they are behind and will probably lose search market share but I wont bet against their data and proprietary tensor core iterations Microsoft small longheld position Meta no position due to longstanding antipathy plus I think they are behind with AI and the metaverse and they have more limited room to grow because 3.5 billion users is a lot, even if many of those are bots. Youre right that YoY growth is a really bad metric to value a high PE stock, as is comparing this quarter this year, vs the same quarter last year. For me to buy a stock with a high PE, it better have higher revenues and higher earnings every quarter and those numbers better have a strong correlation to each other and to EPS those boxes are checked. I like to look at quarterly revenue and EBDITA I have plugged in the numbers, and I would argue that these numbers are both statistically linear. The revenue numbers do a fit a parabolic fit better than a linear fit, hinting at slowing revenue growth. But, the parabolic fit will always be better than the linear fit, whether or not it has meaning, and quarterly earnings reports make for very sparse data. Im expecting roughly linear but moderating revenue and EPS growth and will unload if there is a big surprise to the downside. With linear EPS growth for the next year out, earnings for the next year would be 23 times higher, making the forward PE, which ignores analyst estimates, very reasonable. Growth will probably moderate because of supply chain constraints and moderation in demand. But, Nvidia doesnt need a PE close between 20 and 30 a year out at these prices because highgrowth market leaders always command a PE premium. But, its very plausible that revenue growth is slowing because TSMs production capacity is a bottleneck and it takes a long time to build new fabs, which TSM is doing. However, Nvidia has historically kept its margins very high when there is strong demand. I think the pertinent historical examples are the last bitcoin bubble preASICs and Cisco around its nosebleed peak with a PE over 200. During the crypt0 bubble Nvidia absolutely crushed it while reddit gamers had daily tantrums about Nvidia charging unfair prices for their GPUs. That lasted until ASICs made it unprofitable to mine with an allpurpose GPU, crypt0 started crashing and Nvidia crashed. Im watching Mag 7 cap ex because Cisco collapsed roughly the month after its biggest customers like Worldcom, ATT, AOL, Qwest, and Sprint started dramatically cutting their cap ex. The now bankrupt Worldcom was an outright criminal fraud that was buying Cisco routers to pretend that they were making money to pump their share prices. So Im worried about demand, Im worried about ASICs, respectively thinking about Cisco and the last crypt0 bubble. The main reason I bought more AVGO because its price is down and because OpenAI is building a new secret chip with Broadcom, which is almost certainly a new ASIC chip that will rely on Broadcom and TSM. Also, broadcom should benefit from its auto and manufacturing chips and cell phone sales will probably pick up if rates go down and its a given that they will go down. But, major risks are that the economy is definitely slowing by almost any metric and the Fed is always late with their rate moves, with their backwardlooking data analysis, and whats bad for the economy is bad for everyone. Also, from now to October is historically a very bad time for semis and Wall Street knows it. Also, we know that if investors revolt on spend, CEOs like Zuck will dramatically cut back on cap ex, like he did after the Metaverse crash. I think if one megacap CEO cuts back on GPU spend, they all will, as I feel they are defensively spending to not get left behind, so the script can flip and growth can turn into misses in a hurry. Finally, I feel that most semi and software stocks are overvalued and catching AI tailwinds for no reason and this will hurt the few stocks with good performance, because hedge algos will work to keep correlated pairs of stocks correlated. The conflict between Iran and Israel could blow up in the near future. Also, the performance of bigger and bigger transformers could hit a wall, but I dont think theres evidence of that yet. I dont think humans are special and that there are intrinsic limits about what humans can do and future AI cant. However, better GPUs will someday be locked down even in the U.S., as a national security issue. But, I have a longterm horizon, and the megacaps that are pumping money into NVDA havent cut back on cap ex yet. Nadela says there is still increasing cloud demand and the probability that he is telling truth is greater than the probability that he is lying. I can afford to be wrong about the future and Ill still pay a lot of taxes when I exit.

But with this case, the risk for Alphabet is to be split up. The nightmare scenario for Google is be to forced to into separate search and ad companies. And this ruling will like change their incentives and how they do business. Previously, if you hold search in isolation, its not hard to compete against Google, its impossible to do so and turn a profit. Case in point, Google is paying 15B annually to Apple to remain the default search on iPhones. Its likely not possible to make that much money on a product that is purely used for search. Take the 15B off the table, and Apples incentives change. Googles playbook has always been to build some ecosystem e.g. search, chrome, gmail, drive, photos, maps, much of android, etc, then to leverage that ecosystem to build outstanding ad products, then to leverage that ad revenue to maintain the dominance of their ecosystem. Like Coke needs Pepsi to ensure the dont have a distribution monopoly, moving forward Google is going to need there to be a viable alternative to their ecosytem in order to mitigate the risk of being broken up. Why Apple? From Googles perspective these are the devices that yield the least ad revenue. Since iOS version 14.5 third party cookies have been disabled on Apple devices. Additionally, Apples webkit used to build browsers on iPhone has prevented Googles 3p cookie alternative for advertising privacy sandbox API from being built into the iPhone version of Chrome. Even then, Safari use is currently gaining marketshare. Simply put, if Google has to give up marketshare, this is exactly the segment of the population that gives them the least advertising revenue. From Apples perspective there are 2 industry shifts that might give them an edge. First, because they are not beholden to advertising dollars, theyre not incentivized to build a search product that tracks their users. They would be able to say that their devices allow for privacy, and that their search results are unbiased by ad revenue. Id also suspect that they would lean further into LLM results and integration through Siri. This will be harder for Google because they have always had an unspoken deal with publishers whatever websites, reddit, the new york times, etc. From a publishers perspective, they have been happy to have Google scrape their websites since search will direct traffic to you and then their ad exchange will monetize users that land on your page. But now, privacy features reduce ad revenue per ad and LLM based answers will prevent users from landing on publisher sites in the first place. Because Apple does not make money through advertising and wont face the same pressure from these forces, they may be able to develop the next generation of search. Again, the outcome of this is still very uncertain, but it is much different than MSFT trying to build bing.

The hole in the US balance of payments is slowly widening, in the second quarter the current account deficit reached 266.7 bln, over the last 4 quarters it amounted to 0.95 trillion. A large deficit of 1.1 trillion a year in goods is partially offset by the services sector 288 bln. The revenue situation continued to deteriorate 144 bln yy. One of the problems here in recent years has been the fall in US net investment income to 0.09 of GDP, which had been as high as 11.5 of GDP before 2020, but rising interest rates and a relatively strong dollar have brought it to near zero. More and more debt has to be paid, in this sense the dollar is a fundamentally unstable currency that if rates fall too quickly riskadjusted of course will come under pressure due to reduced capital inflows, if rates remain elevated will remain strong in the moment but will continue to face further current account degradation and problems over the long term horizon. Especially given that the commodity deficit is only growing so far the last 4 months have averaged around 100 bln monthly, i.e. approaching 1.2 trillion annualized levels. And this is despite the fact that over the last 15 years the US has shifted from being a net energy importer to a net energy exporter, but everything it has saved on that has been spent on something else. Total external liabilities on the international investment position rose by 7.6 trillion to a record 57.1 trillion last year, while assets only rose by 3.2 trillion to 35.8 trillion, the net international investment position is negative at 21.3 trillion, or 75 of GDP. At some point, this imbalance will have to be unloaded on foreign investors, but what form and when?

In March 2018, Apple added the option to iOS 11.3 to unthrottle your phone. before that, your phone would artificially be slowed down with each update the CPU clock rate would be substantially reduced. Most people really just need a phone that does all the stuff that iPhones have been doing for 10 years and dont need any of the new features or storage or whatever. Without them artificially slowing it down anymore, performance stayed the same because solid state devices dont wear out. Batteries do wear out, but people just started replacing their batteries every 5 years. Its a cheap part. Solid state memory does eventually develop write fatigue where bits cant be overwritten anymore, but, with load leveling which all solid state memory does and typical consumer phone usage, this would take decades to happen. Basically Apple got screwed when they got sued for slowing down their phones. In the end it probably cost them a half trillion dollars in revenue since then.

So the reason that happens is because of Apple refusing to use the RCS protocol for messaging like everybody else or to release iMessage to anybody but themselves. It means that anybody texting between Android and iPhone defaults back to SMS which is an older standard that doesnt support rich texting features such as multimedia or pictures larger than like 100 kilobytes. The good news is that Apple finally caved and announced last year that they will be adopting RCS for iOS 18 meaning the blurred images and videos thing shouldnt be a problem anymore. The bad news is that Apples entire mobile device identity for a period of years was based on blue bubble vs green bubble which made them delay this adoption by an extra 5 years or so.

People are missing the processor changes processors have not gotten noticeably faster since we reached the theoretical lower limit for gates several years ago. I think you messed up your time machine mate, this is 2024. We are hardly at the theoretical lower limit, and in fact we are seeing a spectacular uptick in CPU upgrades in recent years. Largely due to increased competition and ASML processes maturing. From iPhone 14 pro to iPhone 15pro Apple still went from a 4 to 3nm process, and made 20 CPU speed increase and 30 graphics speed. Thats a very respectable jump for a generation. I dont know about the newest one. I think the not noticeable has a lot to do with it being a phone and at some point there is a diminishing return to how much processing power is useful. Many people dont game on their phones and if they do the games are often designed for 5 generation old patatoes. Then with increased local AI capability that requires big compute locally, but it remains to be seen how enthousiastically people will receive it.

For a typical user, Processing speed on a 4x3 screen isnt important. For most people, as long as they can scroll texts, or watch FBTic Toc vids, thats all that matters. I agree. Anyone with more than two monitors or especially large monitors knows that there is a limit to how much input a human can absorb at any moment. I can only see so many things at once, but when I want to know something I want to know it immediately and with the fewest steps possible. AI can help anticipate what I will want to know based on what Ive wanted to know previously. Example Im watching football and a starter goes down. AI might know that I often pull up depth charts in that scenario. AI might know that I want to know if that player is available in my fantasy leagues. A device might be able to display that information for me in a digestible way without opening ESPN.com or looking it up. Example Im on a call for work and someone says does anyone know anyone at ________? AI knows I normally search my contacts. AI displays the contacts for me in a digestible way in real time. Thats the leap, I think. Anticipatory AI with an AR overlay. We all know our phones are really our pocket computers. We have desktops, laptops, and pockets which we stubbornly call phones. A pocket that is always with me and supporting me in real time using AI and providing me with information via wearable tech is a massive leap. So just like the Newton and Palm Pilot heralded the iPhone, Google Glass and SiriAlexa are the meh products that herald the next multitrillion dollar advance.

The combination of technological improvements in 2018, increased accessibility, heightened public awareness, and affordability has driven the recent popularity of AI models. These models were not as easily accessible or capable in the past, which is why their popularity has surged only recently. With this in mind, I do believe there is significant potential for technological advancements and transformations across many aspects of society, which meets the criteria to be considered a revolution. Here are some reasons to back my opinion. Ubiquity AI will likely become increasingly integrated into everyday life, from personal assistants to tools that help with education, work, and healthcare. AI could become as commonplace as smartphones are today, providing support across a wide range of tasks. Automation Many industries are likely to undergo significant changes as AI automates routine tasks. This could increase efficiency but may also lead to shifts in the job market, requiring new skills and adaptation. Innovation AI will drive innovation in fields such as medicine, finance, and engineering by analyzing large datasets, optimizing processes, and even discovering new materials or drugs. Regulation Governments and organizations may need to develop new regulations to manage the impact of AI, ensuring it benefits society while mitigating potential risks. HumanAI Collaboration AI is likely to evolve as a tool that augments human abilities rather than replacing them. Collaborative AI could enhance creativity, problemsolving, and decisionmaking across various domains. Education and Skills Development There will be a growing need for education systems to adapt, teaching new skills that allow people to work effectively with AI and harness its potential. Societal Changes The widespread adoption of AI could lead to societal changes, such as shifts in how we work, communicate, and even understand our own identities in relation to intelligent systems.. In summary, the future of AI holds both exciting possibilities and complex challenges. The ongoing revolution is likely to redefine industries, economies, and nations.

Are we moving towards arm based pcs ?

possibly, intel is a national security company, folks dont really understand that the US wont let them die a fast death. the problem is that govt prop up tends to make companies lazy, see boeing. if they figure it out, they will do great, if they dont, it will be a money tar pit.
as a gamer, not buying it if i cant play AAA games on an ARM cpu.

Ive been hearing about the death of intel for 30 years. While I dont think much of their business, I dont think that intel is going to die on us. Windows on arm is not a great product yet, it still has a long ways to go. Just acting like intel will die is a bad idea. From an intel going away standpoint, there is too much hardware and software that only runs on x86 and intel. From a stock holder standpoint, I wouldnt be investing in intel either. Intel has definitely screwed the pooch with this massive recall that they are facing.

Even if x86 is dead that doesnt mean ARM wins, or that intel loses. Arm vs x86 has nothing to do with AI, they both suck at it as it stands which keeps Jensen in shiny Jackets. Theres also nothing stopping Intel from developing their own RISC chips or pushing riscv. Or doing this while moving x86 to a legacy platform and still making money supporting it for 50 years as it slowly dies, like IBM. If ARM wins yeah you are right intel could license it and just be a foundry, or do more and be like Qualcomm. Or we can remain with the current mix of ARM slanted moble market and x86 on desktop and server. If riscv wins ARM could be worth nothing at all. Intel loses because that is the nature of the Intel, not because of x86.

I daily a ARM Windows laptop for nearly a year now. My desktop runs an AMD CPU. I dont have any modern Intel products as I think they are shit. I am an Intel investor. Some ARM processors might be better than some x86 processors, but its a misunderstanding that you cant achieve the efficiency of ARM processors with x86. Modern CPUs all run microcode, so the architecture is pretty much irrelevant, the performance and efficiency depends on the design of the chip and the manufacturing process. Apple Silicon is great because they allow very big dies and the most modern manufacturing techniques, which results in expensive and very good chips. Every chip manufacturer has its own go at those decisions. AI is overhyped. The PC architecture that includes the use of x86 processord will NOT die. Take a look at the number of attempts that have been made, including from intel! Im writing those lines from an ARM device, that is for me a lot more attractive than any PC notebook can be. But it doesnt replace the consistancy the PC platform has offered, and which is oftentimes critical for the applications PCs are used in. Be realistic. Intel splitted up in 2 parts now chip design and manufacturing. Both are shit at the moment. All 12th, 13th and 14th gen products are inefficient as hell and pretty much defective. Meteor Lake is most obviously a stopgap. But they heard the call and the next design manufactured by TSMC looks very promising. Manufacturing will take a little bit longer to recover, but the investments have been made, they do have all the best stuff coming up again. Those were my objective arguments, now to the stuff I dont understand and probably will never Investors Intel itself has big challenges at the moment. Their recent chips are essentially dying. They are trying to lie themselves out of the issues, but a complete recall of not only desktop chips, but at least the more powerful notebook chips is very possible. I can imagine this takes a dent into the stock again in the coming months, this is when I will buy more stock.

Qualcomm is beating earnings YoY consistently. With Edge AI, IoT for automotive, and releasing 5G chips for sub 100 phones to compete with Mediatek I think theyre going to see huge growth. At 22X PE ratio, theyre a bargain right now.

People here think about the densiest chips like highend CPUs and memories, but forget that there are way more other components that must be built on larger node process transceivers, power supply devices, PHYs, modems, level shifters, smaller microcontrollers that go into appliances, cars, etc. A lot of things have electronics inside today. Companies like TXN, INTC, NXPI wont go anywhere soon.
arm is barely profitable, nvidia is the way

Intel needs to lay off the useless overpaid middle and upper management entirely and offer better pay and above competitive working conditions for the people designing and building their chips. Well the revenue model is actually pretty insane, albeit quite unique. Customers pay you to license IP, then pay you to license software to develop for that IP, then pay you royalties for every chip produced, rinse and repeat with multi year contract and a constant stream on new shiny IP. As companies try to pack more hardware features into their devices compute subsystems and the IP increases in complexity, arm have every excuse to start jacking up royalties to boost their revenue into the 10s of billions, and with huge market share in key sectors smartphone, and growing market share in infraAIlaptopetc, that could absolutely be sustainable.
